meeting_annotations.speaker: Shu Hu
meeting_annotations.transcript: Jordi that's an excellent question. I think electrochemistry is very fundamental to many fields but I think the topic here really calls for our serious consideration of what electrochemistry cannot do now or in other words what other fields that we can learn from that electrochemistry can do which really boosts the outreach of electrochemistry. For example what we can learn from the heterogeneous catalysis is that these reactions happen at an elevated temperature. Can we drive the electrochemistry at elevated temperature in the gas phase or in the vapor phase? I think there are quite a few work now to show that you can do electrochemistry at above the solvent boiling point but using like a solid state electrolyte or membrane.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Shu Hu
meeting_annotations.transcript: For example also in terms of photocatalysis not photoelectro catalysis. Photocatalysis means you are generating reducing and oxidizing agents on the same liquid interface which means you can really do locally redox reactions. That is not available in electrochemistry not just yet. So can we learn something from what photochemistry can do and really boost the capability of electrocatalysis because because all these I think just take a very traditional field for example photocorrosion. Corrosion is all local that means there exist a locally different potentials during the corrosion sites and you could oxidize the material and reducing oxygen at the same time that builds a locally galvanic cell. So can we learn something from there in terms of corrosion process and actually but in an electrocatalysis way to produce fuels or some other things some useful chemicals. So that's that's answer your question.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Shu Hu
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah and to I think Jenny brings a really interesting point. Just to build on that the introducing electrical field is what really electrochemistry what is theory and hard can do. And of course we know we know little about the electrochemical double layer its formation composition its dynamics under operating conditions especially how that behaves not in a model system but also in an actual fuel cell type of or MEA type of design. So that is unknown. And and also what I think here is that many electrocatalysts now are oriented towards oxides nitrides and carbides. Of course you would like to have electrocatalyst that are conductive which means it is metallic but many of these oxides or sulfides or nitrides they're actually semiconductors or having a band gap. Of course they have defects but how do we understand the defects and electronic structure that influence the catalytic reactions. So I think that is not discussed too much we basically just treat electrocatalyst as a metal. What if we think differently? So there's so that that's also not too much discussed.
